description: From Middle French offendre, from Latin offendō (“strike, blunder, commit an offense”), from ob- (“against”) + *fendō (“strike”).

verbs.description: offend (third-person singular simple present offends, present participle offending, simple past and past participle offended)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To hurt the feelings of; to displease; to make angry; to insult.
(intransitive) To feel or become offended; to take insult.
examples: Don't worry. I don't offend easily.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To annoy, cause discomfort or resent.
examples: Physically enjoyable frivolity can still offend the conscience

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To sin, transgress divine law or moral rules.
(transitive) To transgress or violate a law or moral requirement.
(obsolete, transitive, archaic, biblical) To cause to stumble; to cause to sin or to fall.
examples: "If any man offend not (stumbles not, is not tripped up) in word, the same is a perfect man."
